I think front back and side bumper cameras are going to be the last big safety improvement before we move entirely to self driving cars for most things. Being able to have the car hold a lane, or warn you you're drifting over lane lines without signalling (useful if you fall asleep and start to drift), brake for you if it detects an imminent crash, and honestly most importantly, help you get in and out of tight parking situations, which is where the majority of accidents actually occur, even if they're generally more minor. Not all of them are minor of course, since oncoming cars hitting you at speed is never good, but the technologies listed above can also help prevent such an accident if backup cams and such aren't sufficient to avoid it.

Back when I worked with the crew on the show Pimp My Ride, we pimped-out one of these 1886 Benzes, but it was an original.  We saw the diameter of those rims and were like "DAY-um!"  So we upped it to a pair of 42" spinning rims in back running 16" wide rubber, a mini 12" rim in front, and an electric low-rider system with the battery underslung beneath the floorboard.  We swapped the single-cylinder 3 HP engine for a supercharged 451 Mopar Stroker Short Block with Nitrous Oxide, and it dyno'ed at 873 HP with mad torque at the low end, too.  But don't think we went cheap-ass on the interior just because it's an open-top.  Naw, cuz-- we went 100% ermine fur on the seats and floorboard, and custom-fit an ermine sock over the steering handle.  A 1968 Hurst Long Boy shifter replaced that lame-ass throttle bar he's holding on to.  Time trials showed us we were on the right track: the stock original Benz did the quarter mile in 3 minutes 27.42 seconds.  Pimped, we got that down to 9.1 seconds for real.  And you should see this thing bouncin' in Crenshaw, yo!

Josef Božek built a working steam-powered car in 1816, seventy years before this "world's first car." By the early 1830s, London had steam-powered buses for public transit, which saw huge cost and quality improvements over horse-drawn carriages. Development continued through the middle of the 19th century in both England and the U.S., but at least by 1871, the suitably-named John Wesley Carhart had invented a working car that could drive on public roads, not on tracks. On July 16, 1878, a steam-powered car from Oshkosh completed a 201 mile race in less than 33 and a half hours, which far outpaced anything animals could achieve. And in 1881, Gustave Trouvé demonstrated a practical electric tricycle in Paris.

Whatever you think of Édouard Delamare-Deboutteville, it seems like calling this the "World's First Car" is an exaggeration. This is (arguably) the first practical gasoline-powered car, but electric and steam cars definitely preceded it.

What about the ancient mathematician and engineer Hero of Alexandria's self-propelled gravity-powered programmable cart, which was used for ancient theater? It may not have been used for transportation, but the potenial and basic idea for a primitive automobile was there, 2 thousand years ago in Roman Egypt.


Speaking of Hero of Alexandria, he is credited with the invention of a steam-powered device called an aeolipile (aka the "Hero engine").


So just imagine how different history would have turned out if Hero or somebody shortly after him had combined his theater cart with his steam device? Imagine if the ancient Romans had been the ones to invent the automobile?


Just something to think about.

Technology, no matter how "reliable", will not save us from ourselves. Paying attention to the world around you while you are driving does not require a great deal of effort. Removing distractions may require more effort, knowing that many folk have become very attached to their "devices". Turn off the "phones" and other such things...put them in the trunk if you have to...or learn to use a hands-free system! Driving doesn't need to be "boring" and it really shouldn't be "thrilling" (at least, not on public roads). Granted, "self-driving" cars may become the normal, just as auto-pilot did in aircraft. That does not mean we should not have to learn to drive, just as men and women are still required to learn how to fly an aircraft in order to become a pilot. That being said, I do enjoy driving, and will continue to, so long as my health allows.

Start in the 1830s, with Scotland’s Robert Anderson, whose motorized carriage was built sometime between 1832 and ’39. Batteries (galvanic cells) were not yet rechargeable, so it was more parlor trick (“Look! No horse nor ox, yet it moves!”) than a transportation device. Another Scot, Robert Davidson of Aberdeen, built a prototype electric locomotive in 1837. A bigger, better version, demonstrated in 1841, could go 1.5 miles at 4 mph towing six tons. Then it needed new batteries. This impressive performance so alarmed railway workers (who saw it as a threat to their jobs tending steam engines) that they destroyed Davidson’s devil machine, which he’d named "Galvani."

According to Sam Peltzman, the introduction of safety features for motor vehicle traffic decreases the severity for vehicle occupants, but as drivers feel safer, they drive more recklessly. This risk compensating behavior leads to an increase of accident numbers. Often the non-occupants (pedestrians, bikers, etc.) then have the higher risk. For seat belts (mandatory in NY since 1984) the overall effect for traffic death was negligible.

Its weird thinking about it afterward realizing you let go of the brakes just before impact or needling the car to turn and reapplying, rinse.. repeat .. until you stop where you want to be.

I'd like to point out that you are maximizing the time over which deceleration happens, not the distance. The larger distance is a byproduct. Momentum is mass * velocity, and in order to change momentum an impulse is required, which is force * time. Since in a car collision you are attempting to minimize the force acting on the passengers, you are maximizing the time over which the force is exerted. The larger distance is simply a factor of the current state of material science and engineering and is by no means a requirement.

ABS is not for faster braking but for controlled braking.

This is a very good video, as usual from this channel, but disappointed in some errors or misinterpretations. Although the Benz is often considered the first "production" horseless carriage (a handful were made), there were similar ideas built by the French 100 years earlier and some really primitive concepts even centuries before them. As for ABS brakes, the tech had been around for rail and aviation for decades but Chrysler, of all companies, put it on some cars in the early 70s. Meanwhile airbags had been offered for sale 10 years before any Mercedes-Benz by GM on their higher end Cadillacs and Oldsmobiles and that's only after Chrysler declined to install the invention in its cars as early as the 1950s. This video was sponsored by Mercedes-Benz though, so there's that. But hey, if Derek ever wants to collaborate on future automotive videos, I'd be thrilled to participate :)

Well you're not really decreasing the magnitude of the acceleration. By increasing the time over which the momentum is transferred, you're deceasing the average amount of force being applied to the passengers at any one moment. Now this isn't to say that the total amount of force applied over time changes, because it doesn't, but rather just the average force being applied in any one instant is lower. This follows from the impulse-momentum law, i.e. F=∆p/∆t, where F is force, p is momentum and t is time.
